content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would reason that the game is essentially a repeated version of a one-time game where you have two options: R and B. In this one-time game, if both players choose R, they get 45$, if one chooses R and the other chooses B, the R player gets 0$ while the B player gets 35$. If both choose B, each gets 40$.

In terms of expected payoff, choosing R gives a potential outcome of 45$ (if they also pick R), but if they always pick B, you get 0$, which happens 75% of the time (since B is a more attractive option for them due to the higher payoff when they play against an R choice). In contrast, choosing B gives a potential outcome of 40$ regardless of their choice.

Since the game has 75 rounds, and since B provides a guaranteed 40$ in each round where your opponent chooses B (which happens 30 times out of 75), it would seem rational to choose B as it guarantees a higher average payoff over the long run compared to choosing R.

So my choice would be {B}. However, it's important to note that this reasoning assumes that your opponent is rational and will indeed choose the strategy that gives them a higher expected payoff in the long run (which in this case is B as well). If they choose irrationally or unpredictably, the optimal choice may change.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this situation where both you and your opponent chose B in the previous round, you will again choose B for the upcoming round to maintain the strategy of always choosing the option that guarantees a higher payout (40$ compared to 35$). This ensures that you maximize your expected earnings over the long run, given that your opponent is also following a rational strategy and will likely continue to pick B in future rounds.

In this situation where both you and your opponent have been choosing B consistently for multiple rounds, the game remains unchanged since neither player has a dominant strategy that would lead to a higher expected payoff in every round. However, as you are participating in a lab experiment with 75 rounds, it is important to consider your overall earnings over the entire game rather than just focusing on individual rounds.

In this case, by consistently choosing B, you will receive 40$ in each of the 75 rounds for a total of 3,000$ (75 * 40). If, at any point during the game, your opponent were to switch strategies and start picking R, they would only receive 1,875$ (75 * 25) in total. This means that you are likely to earn more money by consistently choosing B than by switching strategies and potentially earning less due to the unpredictability of your opponent's choices.

Therefore, I recommend continuing to choose B for the upcoming round, as it still guarantees a higher expected payout (3,000$ compared to 1,875$) over the long run given that your opponent is also following a rational strategy and will likely continue to pick B in future rounds.

Alternatively, if your opponent does switch to R as well, the payoff structure of the game would change, and both players could be earning more money overall by consistently choosing R instead of B.
